courseDetails.title: How to Set Limits with Love - Raising Strong-Willed Kids
courseDetails.shortDescription: Increase cooperation, communication, and collaboration while parenting challenging kids
courseDetails.longDescription:
Traditional systems of rewards and consequences can deflate a child's sense of confidence and identity in a heartbeat.   


In this short course, we'll evaluate your current approach to parenting, and with that information, figure out strategies to raise your child's confidence while inspiring cooperation, collaboration, and connection. 


Say goodbye to defiant kids who disrespect your rules.


"Setting Limits with Love" will teach you effective parenting techniques for raising a child that honors your boundaries, appreciates your rules, and wants a healthy parent-child relationship with you.


This course is designed for parents seeking a mindful and empathetic approach to discipline. You'll gain insights and practical tools to navigate the most challenging situations with grace and understanding.


The course starts with a quick exercise that will illuminate which parts of your current approach are working and which are inadvertently making parenting harder for you.


Then, we'll open up a world of new ideas for how to help your unique child cooperate and feel fully respected in the process. 


Throughout the course, we'll explore key concepts related to:

  • Communicating with kids who don't listen

  • Building mutual respect for the whole family

  • Collaborating on problems before they get worse


Concrete tips (like "articulating your child's point of view before your own" and "tackling the smallest problem as a team first") provide actionable steps to strengthen the bond between you and your child while promoting great behavior.


You'll emerge from this course feeling confident and competent at setting limits with love. You'll feel equipped to create an environment at home that sets your child up to thrive for years to come.


Other course highlights include:


  1. Understanding new tools for uncovering the underlying causes of behavior

  2. Exploring "Connection Management" as an alternative to traditional behavior management strategies

  3. Learning effective communication techniques to engage with your child empathetically

  4. Embracing collaboration as a powerful tool for setting limits with love

  5. Cultivating a culture of teamwork and problem-solving within your family


Join Rachel Sklar, your course leader and long-time parenting coach, as you update your parenting approach and build deeper connections with your child.


Create more peace at home and a family culture of mutual respect and cooperation.
targetAudiences: This course is for parents of strong-willed children ages 4 to 14.

courseDetails.title: ETABS & Safe in R.C.C 3m Cantilever Project without cracked
courseDetails.shortDescription: Modeling and design of the project using flat slab (thickness, reinforcement, short term, and long term deflection)
courseDetails.longDescription:
This course not just a tutorial on software ETABS and SAFE but it is a complete understanding about structural design analysis, how civil engineer must begin with the project, how he/she must think, how we can determine the dimension of the element before modeling them check it in the software. In this course we will show structural design of a slab with 3m cantilever. First of all we will review and study the architectural plan of the project then we will prepare the structural plan of the slab to import it into ETABS and SAFE using AutoCad. After this we will on the determination of the slab thickness. Also we will check the deflection of the slab on short term deflection and long term deflection with existence of glasses wall so the deflection must be checked well to prevent cracked and glass break. In addition to choose the best material of this project with the necessary reinforcement needed for this flat slab. Finally we draw the structural executive plans of this slab using AutoCAD.

We study the need of using drop beam or deep beam and we will the design this beam if necessary using a very important software custom for beam design
targetAudiences: Beginner and Expert

Tekla structures is a building information modeling software able to model structures that incorporate different kinds of building materials, including steel, concrete, timber, and glass.

Tekla structures the most advanced structural BIM software, lets you create, combine, manage and share multi-material 3D models packed with valuable construction information.

With Tekla structures you can create accurate information-rich 3D models that have all the structural data you need to build and maintain any type of structure.

You can also import, export and link your data with other software solutions, digital construction tools and fabrication machinery for smoother workflow.

In this course we will do a practice by modeling a steel structure on Tekla the modeling will include all the steel structural elements (beams, columns, rails, purlins, frame, bracing, truss, concrete slab,  foundations and connections)

Also we will show in this course how we can export the drawings from Tekla structures software to other software

The project that will worked on is a steel hangar structure with length 75m and width 25m

In this course we will show the different standard steel sections I Section (HP, M, S, W); C-Shape; Angle Sections; and Pipes sections we will show how we can model and using these different structural steel sections how you define them and design

The dimensions and properties for structural sections commonly used in steel building structure design and construction are given in this course in addition to all design consideration and  proper material availability and specification according the AISC code.

courseDetails.title: STAAD Pro V8 Industrial Steel Warehouse Design from A to Z
courseDetails.shortDescription: STAAD Pro V8 Industrial Steel Warehouse Design from A to Z
courseDetails.longDescription:
This course teaches you all the things required for the structural analysis and design of a steel warehouse building. This course, as the title says, doesn't require you to have any prior experience in this software or any other structural design software. It will teach all the aspects of the software from very basic and will take you to the higher levels of the software as the course progresses. The course has been very systematically arranged so that you can best understand the software. Once you complete this course, you will have all the necessary knowledge to do structural design of a steel warehouse. You can work as a structural designer or can do the structural design of buildings on your own projects.

You will be learning all you need to know about structural analysis steel warehouse buildings using STAAD Pro in your professional career according to international norms like American codes and standards. The course will be discussing very essential topics, including assigning load combinations according to ASCE7/IBC, wind and seismic load applications according to ASCE and UBC 97 respectively as well as the design. Moreover, you will learn how to check your structure's deflection against the serviceability requirements/limits and optimization of steel section sizes as per codes ASCE7/IBC. Furthermore, design of composite beam, deck slab, purlins, truss, generating reports, getting base support reactions, beam end forces, stress ratios of members, member take off, using STAAD editor, Section Wizard and many more interesting and important topics like steel material properties and mechanics will be discussed in the course.

STAAD Pro stands for Structural Analysis and design. STAAD Pro v8i Software is widely used in analyzing and designing structures – buildings, bridges, towers, transportation, industrial and utility structures. In this Software you will show a detail analysis and design of all the structural elements of steel warehouse building under gravity loads (dead and live) and lateral loads (earthquake and wind)
targetAudiences: ivil Engineering Students who want to learn structural design

courseDetails.shortDescription: Structural design of a tower with diff earthquake system (shear wall, moment frame, dual system, use viscous damper)

With the last version of ETABS (2019)

First of all we will show the newest features in ETABS v19

Also we will learn in this course what is outrigger and how we can define and modeling it into ETABS V19 and we will show the benefits of using outrigger in high rise building very important part will show you the needs of well study of damper parameters when structural designing Tall Buildings

The role of a Digital Products and Services Business Analyst (BA) is crucial in ensuring the success and efficiency of digital products and services within a company. They bridge the gap between technical teams and business stakeholders, ensuring that digital products align with business goals and meet user needs. Here's an overview of their key functionalities:


Requirement Gathering and Analysis: BAs work closely with stakeholders to understand business objectives and translate them into technical requirements for digital products and services.


Documentation and Communication: They document requirements, specifications, and user stories in a clear and concise manner, facilitating communication between technical and non-technical teams.


User Experience (UX) Analysis: They analyze user feedback, behavior, and market trends to improve the user experience of digital products and services.


Data Analysis: DPS BAs analyze data metrics to assess the performance of digital products and services, identify areas for improvement, and make data-driven recommendations.


Quality Assurance: They collaborate with quality assurance teams to ensure that digital products meet quality standards and functional requirements.


Project Management: They assist in project planning, scheduling, and coordination, ensuring that digital projects are delivered on time and within budget.


Learning about digital products and services business analysis is important for companies for several reasons:


Strategic Alignment: By understanding business goals and user needs, BAs ensure that digital products and services are aligned with the overall strategy of the company.


Cost Reduction and Efficiency: Effective analysis and requirements gathering help in minimizing rework and optimizing resources, leading to cost reduction and increased efficiency.


Competitive Advantage: A deep understanding of digital products and services allows companies to stay competitive in the rapidly evolving digital landscape.


Customer Satisfaction: By focusing on user experience and continuously improving digital products, companies can enhance customer satisfaction and loyalty.


Innovation: BAs play a crucial role in driving innovation by identifying opportunities for new digital products and services that meet emerging market needs.


In terms of career building, expertise in digital products and services business analysis can open up various opportunities in industries ranging from technology and e-commerce to finance and healthcare. Companies are increasingly recognizing the importance of digital transformation, making professionals with skills in this area highly sought after. Additionally, the role offers room for growth into leadership positions such as Product Manager or Business Analyst Manager as one gains experience and expertise in the field. Continuous learning and staying updated with industry trends and technologies are essential for success in this dynamic and rapidly evolving field.
targetAudiences: No special requirements. A course for anyone who wants to build career in business analysis or digital projects

Getting Started with Google Workspace

User Management and Provisioning

Creating and Managing User Accounts

This module will dive deep into user management, one of the most critical aspects of Google Workspace administration. You'll discover how to create and manage user accounts, set up group email aliases, and control access to various apps and services.

Email Configuration and Management

Collaboration with Google Drive and Docs

Calendar and Meeting Management

Security and Compliance

Best Practices and Advanced Topics

Advanced Tips and Tricks

Conclusion

By completing the Professional Google Workspace Administrator course, you'll be well-prepared to take on the role of an efficient and skilled administrator. What is the Real Estate Business?

The real estate business encompasses all activities related to the buying, selling, renting, development, and management of land and buildings. This includes:

  • Residential Real Estate: Homes, apartments, condominiums, and other housing types.

  • Commercial Real Estate: Office buildings, retail spaces, warehouses, industrial properties, hotels, and more.

  • Land: Undeveloped land, agricultural land, and properties with development potential.

  • Real Estate Brokerage: Facilitating transactions between buyers and sellers.

  • Real Estate Development: Transforming land into usable properties.

  • Property Management: Overseeing the operations of rental properties.


Why is Learning About the Real Estate Business Important for Companies and Managers?


Real estate knowledge has significant implications for businesses, regardless of their core industry:

  • Cost Management: Real estate is often a company's second-largest expense after personnel costs. Understanding lease negotiations, property values, and market trends is crucial for making informed financial decisions.

  • Business Expansion: When a company intends to grow, strategic real estate decisions play a vital role. Site selection, facility planning, and understanding local land-use regulations are essential for successfully scaling operations.

  • Asset Optimization: Companies often own more real estate than they need. Learning about sale-leaseback options or subleasing excess space can unlock hidden capital and improve a company's bottom line.

  • Workplace Strategy: The design and function of workplaces significantly affect employee productivity, well-being, and recruitment. Real estate knowledge informs optimal workplace strategies.

  • Investment Opportunities: For some larger corporations, investing in real estate can offer diversification and potential for additional revenue streams.


How Real Estate Skills Connect to Global Careers and Professional Services

Skills in the real estate field open doors to a wide range of fulfilling and lucrative global career opportunities:

  • International Real Estate Development: As companies expand globally, those with real estate development experience can contribute to planning and executing new facilities in foreign markets.

  • Global Site Selection: Professionals versed in real estate analysis can help multinational corporations identify the best locations for their operations, considering factors like demographics, infrastructure, and local regulations.

  • Cross-Border Transactions: Facilitating real estate sales and purchases across international borders requires navigating complex legal and financial systems.

  • Hospitality and Tourism: The global hospitality industry is heavily intertwined with real estate. Professionals who understand hotel development and management can have exciting international careers.

  • Consulting Services: Real estate consultants use their expertise to offer a range of services to corporations, investors, and governments worldwide.
targetAudiences: No special requirements. A course for anyone who wants to build career in Real Estate Business

What is the Real Estate Business?  The real estate business encompasses all activities related to the buying, selling, renting, development, and management of land and buildings. This includes:  Residential Real Estate: Homes, apartments, condominiums, and other housing types.  Commercial Real Estate: Office buildings, retail spaces, warehouses, industrial properties, hotels, and more.  Land: Undeveloped land, agricultural land, and properties with development potential.  Real Estate Brokerage: Facilitating transactions between buyers and sellers.  Real Estate Development: Transforming land into usable properties.  Property Management: Overseeing the operations of rental properties.

Why is Learning About the Real Estate Business Important for Companies and Managers?  Real estate knowledge has significant implications for businesses, regardless of their core industry:  Cost Management: Real estate is often a company's second-largest expense after personnel costs. Understanding lease negotiations, property values, and market trends is crucial for making informed financial decisions.  Business Expansion: When a company intends to grow, strategic real estate decisions play a vital role. Site selection, facility planning, and understanding local land-use regulations are essential for successfully scaling operations.  Asset Optimization: Companies often own more real estate than they need. Learning about sale-leaseback options or subleasing excess space can unlock hidden capital and improve a company's bottom line.  Workplace Strategy: The design and function of workplaces significantly affect employee productivity, well-being, and recruitment. Real estate knowledge informs optimal workplace strategies.  Investment Opportunities: For some larger corporations, investing in real estate can offer diversification and potential for additional revenue streams.

How Real Estate Skills Connect to Global Careers and Professional Services  Skills in the real estate field open doors to a wide range of fulfilling and lucrative global career opportunities:  International Real Estate Development: As companies expand globally, those with real estate development experience can contribute to planning and executing new facilities in foreign markets.  Global Site Selection: Professionals versed in real estate analysis can help multinational corporations identify the best locations for their operations, considering factors like demographics, infrastructure, and local regulations.  Cross-Border Transactions: Facilitating real estate sales and purchases across international borders requires navigating complex legal and financial systems.  Hospitality and Tourism: The global hospitality industry is heavily intertwined with real estate. Professionals who understand hotel development and management can have exciting international careers.  Consulting Services: Real estate consultants use their expertise to offer a range of services to corporations, investors, and governments worldwide.

courseDetails.title: Mastering Cybersecurity Ransomware Incident Response (101)
courseDetails.shortDescription: Cybersecurity, Ransomware Incident Response, Cybersecurity Awareness, Vulnerability Management, Ransomware Attacks
courseDetails.longDescription:
Mastering Cybersecurity Ransomware Incident Response (101)

In today's digital age, the threat of ransomware looms large over organizations of all sizes and across various industries. Ransomware attacks can be catastrophic, resulting in data loss, financial damages, and reputational harm. To effectively combat this growing menace, professionals in the field of cybersecurity need to be well-prepared with the right knowledge and skills. That's where the "Master Course: Cybersecurity Ransomware Incident Response" comes into play.

Cybersecurity incident response, particularly in the context of ransomware attacks, is critically important for several reasons:

Financial Impact: Ransomware attacks can result in significant financial losses. Organizations may be required to pay a ransom to regain access to their data, and even if they choose not to pay, they still face costs associated with investigating the incident, restoring systems, and implementing security improvements to prevent future attacks.

Data Loss: Ransomware can lead to the loss of sensitive and critical data. Without a robust incident response plan, organizations may struggle to recover their data or face permanent data loss, which can have serious consequences for their operations.

Reputation Damage: Data breaches and ransomware incidents can seriously damage an organization's reputation. If customers, partners, or the public lose trust in an organization's ability to protect their data, it can lead to a loss of business and credibility.

Legal and Regulatory Consequences: Many countries have data protection laws and regulations that require organizations to take reasonable steps to protect sensitive data. Failing to respond effectively to a ransomware incident can result in legal and regulatory penalties.

Operational Disruption: Ransomware attacks can disrupt an organization's operations, leading to downtime, loss of productivity, and increased operational costs. An effective incident response plan can help minimize these disruptions and facilitate a quicker recovery.

Security Improvement: Incident response provides an opportunity for organizations to learn from the attack and improve their cybersecurity defenses. By analyzing how the attack occurred and what vulnerabilities were exploited, organizations can implement measures to prevent similar incidents in the future.

Containment and Mitigation: A well-executed incident response plan can help contain the spread of ransomware within an organization's network, preventing further damage and data encryption. Quick containment can limit the extent of the breach and reduce the impact.

Legal and Ethical Considerations: Organizations need to consider the ethical and legal implications of paying ransoms. An incident response plan should include a strategy for making these difficult decisions, taking into account the potential consequences and compliance requirements.

Preparedness for Future Attacks: Ransomware attacks are on the rise, and organizations need to be prepared for future incidents. Having a well-documented incident response plan in place can help organizations respond more effectively when the next attack occurs.

In summary, cybersecurity incident response, especially in the case of ransomware, is crucial because it helps organizations minimize financial losses, protect their reputation, comply with legal requirements, and improve their overall security posture. Being prepared for and effectively responding to ransomware incidents is essential in today's cybersecurity landscape.

Ransomware attacks are a persistent and evolving threat in today's digital landscape. The "Master Course: Cybersecurity Ransomware Incident Response" equips you with the essential knowledge and skills to effectively detect, respond to, and recover from ransomware incidents and this course is your key to staying ahead of cybercriminals and protecting your organization's valuable assets. Don't wait until the next attack occurs; enroll now and become a cybersecurity hero in the fight against ransomware.

courseDetails.title: Probability Beyond the Basics:  Part 3
courseDetails.shortDescription: Taking Your Mastery of  Probability to the Next Level
courseDetails.longDescription:
1. If a card is drawn from a well-shuffled deck of 52 cards, what is the probability of getting different types of cards.


2. If five cards - the ten, jack, queen, king and ace of diamonds, are well-shuffled with their face downwards and one card is picked up at random, what is the probability that the card is queen? If the queen is drawn and put aside, what is the probability that the second card picked up is (a) an ace (b) a queen?


3. If defective pens are accidentally mixed with good ones, then how to calculate the probability that the pen taken out is good one?


4. A lot of bulbs contains some defective bulbs. One bulb is drawn at random. What is the probability that this bulb is defective? If bulb drawn is not defective and not replaced, now if one bulb is picked up, what is the probability that this bulb is not defective?


5. A box contains some discs which are numbered. If one disc is drawn, what is the probability that it bears a two digit number, a perfect square number, a number divisible by 5.


6. A dice has six alphabetic faces, one appearing twice. What is the probability of getting (A) and (D)?


7. If a die is dropped at random on the rectangular region, what is the probability that it will land inside the circle with diameter 1m given in figure?


8. A lot consists of ball pens some of which are defective. Nuri will buy the pen if it is good. What is the probability that she will buy the pen drawn at random by the shopkeeper?


9. A game consists of tossing a one rupee coin 3 times and noting its outcome each time. If the result is three heads or three tails, it means winning. Calculate the probability of losing the game?


10. A die has different numbers some appearing twice. The score obtained on throwing it twice is noted in table. What is the probability that the total score is even, 6, and at least 6?

Unlocking Opportunities with a CRISC Certification: Mastering Risk Information Systems and Control

In today's rapidly evolving digital landscape, organizations face an ever-growing need to manage and mitigate risks associated with information systems. Cyber threats, data breaches, and regulatory compliance issues are just a few of the challenges that businesses encounter on a daily basis. This is where professionals certified in Risk Information Systems and Control (CRISC) step in, armed with the knowledge and skills to navigate this complex terrain.

In this master course, we'll explore the world of CRISC certification, its significance, and the doors it can open for those who pursue it.

Understanding CRISC: A Brief Overview

Certified in Risk Information Systems and Control (CRISC) is a globally recognized certification offered by ISACA (Information Systems Audit and Control Association). CRISC is specifically designed for IT and business professionals responsible for managing, controlling, and assuring information risk within an organization. It focuses on building expertise in risk identification, assessment, evaluation, and response.

Why CRISC Matters: The Importance of Risk Management

In an age where data breaches and cybersecurity threats make headlines regularly, the need for effective risk management cannot be overstated. CRISC professionals are uniquely positioned to address these challenges by:

1. Identifying Risks: CRISC-certified individuals can spot vulnerabilities in an organization's information systems and assess their potential impact. This proactive approach enables organizations to address issues before they escalate into major crises.

2. Ensuring Compliance: Regulatory compliance is a top priority for businesses across industries. CRISC certification equips professionals with the knowledge to navigate complex regulatory frameworks and maintain compliance.

3. Strengthening Cybersecurity: With their deep understanding of information risk, CRISC professionals play a crucial role in enhancing an organization's cybersecurity posture. They help create robust defenses and strategies to protect against cyber threats.

4. Enhancing Business Performance: Effective risk management isn't just about minimizing threats; it's also about seizing opportunities. CRISC-certified individuals help organizations make informed decisions by weighing risks against potential rewards.

In an era where information is the lifeblood of organizations, effective risk management is non-negotiable. CRISC certification equips professionals with the skills and knowledge needed to tackle information risks head-on, ensuring the security and success of their organizations.

If you're considering a career in IT risk management, compliance, or information security, or if you're looking to advance in your current role, pursuing CRISC certification is a strategic move that can open a world of opportunities. By mastering Risk Information Systems and Control, you're not only securing your future but also contributing to a safer, more resilient digital world.

courseDetails.longDescription:
CISSP - Certified Information Systems Security Professional

CISSP 101 Course: Your Guide to Becoming a Certified Information Systems Security Professional

Introduction

In today's interconnected world, the protection of sensitive information and the assurance of cybersecurity have become paramount. As technology advances, so do the threats to our digital assets. This is where the Certified Information Systems Security Professional (CISSP) certification comes into play. The CISSP certification is globally recognized and signifies a high level of expertise in information security. In this 101 course, we'll delve into the basics of the CISSP 101 course and explore why it's a crucial step towards a successful career in cybersecurity.

What is CISSP?

Certified Information Systems Security Professional (CISSP) is a renowned certification offered by (ISC)², the International Information System Security Certification Consortium. The CISSP certification is designed for professionals who want to demonstrate their knowledge and expertise in information security and cybersecurity practices.

Why Pursue CISSP Certification?

CISSP certification holds immense value for individuals seeking a career in information security. Here are some reasons why CISSP is highly regarded in the industry:

1. Global Recognition: CISSP is recognized worldwide as a mark of excellence in the field of cybersecurity. Holding this certification opens up opportunities on a global scale.

2. Industry Demand: With the increasing frequency and complexity of cyberattacks, organizations are actively seeking skilled professionals who can safeguard their digital assets. CISSP-certified individuals are in high demand across various industries.

3. Comprehensive Knowledge: The CISSP certification covers a wide range of topics, ensuring that certified professionals have a holistic understanding of security principles, practices, and technologies.

4. Career Advancement: CISSP certification can significantly boost your career. It can open doors to higher-paying positions, leadership roles, and consulting opportunities.

5. Professional Network: Becoming CISSP-certified connects you with a global community of security professionals, providing opportunities for networking, collaboration, and knowledge-sharing.

CISSP 101 Course Overview

The CISSP 101 course serves as an introduction to the world of CISSP certification. It provides foundational knowledge and prepares candidates for the rigorous CISSP exam. Here's what you can expect from the CISSP 101 course:

1. Domain Exploration: The CISSP certification exam is based on eight domains, including Security and Risk Management, Asset Security, Security Architecture and Engineering, Communication and Network Security, Identity and Access Management, Security Assessment and Testing, Security Operations, and Software Development Security. The CISSP 101 course gives you a glimpse into each domain, ensuring you have a solid foundation before diving into the exam preparation.

2. Security Principles: The course covers fundamental security principles, including confidentiality, integrity, availability, and non-repudiation. Understanding these principles is crucial for designing and implementing effective security measures.

3. Security Technologies: CISSP 101 introduces you to a variety of security technologies and tools commonly used in the industry. This knowledge helps you comprehend how different technologies contribute to overall security strategies.

4. Risk Management: Risk management is a critical aspect of information security. The course highlights the importance of risk assessment, analysis, and mitigation strategies to protect an organization's assets.

5. Legal and Ethical Considerations: Information security professionals must navigate legal and ethical challenges. CISSP 101 provides insights into relevant laws, regulations, and ethical practices that impact cybersecurity decisions.

Conclusion

The CISSP 101 course is the gateway to the world of Certified Information Systems Security Professionals. By enrolling in this course, you're taking the first step towards enhancing your knowledge, skills, and career prospects in the cybersecurity field. With the demand for skilled cybersecurity experts at an all-time high, CISSP certification can be your ticket to a fulfilling and impactful career. So, if you're passionate about safeguarding digital assets and contributing to a safer online world, consider embarking on the journey to become a CISSP-certified professional. Your expertise could be the shield that organizations need to fend off the ever-evolving threats in the digital landscape.

2. Asset Security

3. Security Architecture and Engineering

6. Security Assessment and Testing

8. Software Development Security

9. Practice test

To pass of this practice test course, you must score at least 70% on the practice test.

courseDetails.title: Matlab course for wireless communication engineering
courseDetails.shortDescription: A step by step the Matlab codes for BER estimations of different Comm. systems like OFDM and NOMA Comm. systems
courseDetails.longDescription:
This is course is designed for under and post graduate students associated to the electronics and communication engineering department. It has 10 introductions of 30 minutes, each introduction discusses the theoretical explanation and the simulated figures that obtained through the explanation of the course. This course saves many months of hard work.

Using the Matlab program, you will learn:

1-How to estimate the Bit-Error-Rate (BER) performance of different modulation schemes like BPSK, QPSK, 16QAM, 64QAM, and 256QAM over an Additive White Gaussian Noise (AWGN) channel?

2-How to generate and add a Rayleigh fading channel based on the Jakes model?

3-How to mitigate the Rayleigh fading channel effect using different linear equalizer schemes?

4-How to estimate the Bit-Error-Rate (BER) performance over Single-Input-Single-Output Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (SISO-OFDM) communication system over a Rayleigh fading channel?

5-How to extend this work for different Multiple-Input-Multiple-Output (MIMO) configurations like 2×2, and 3×3 MIMO-OFDM communication systems over a Rayleigh fading channel?

6-A general code for BER estimation in case of Nt×Nr configuration for OFDM communication system over a Rayleigh fading channel will be presented, where Nt, is the number of transmitting antennas, and Nr is the number of receiving antennas.

7-Finally, the BER estimation for Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access (NOMA), which used in the 5G communication systems will be presented.
targetAudiences: This is course is designed for under and postgraduate students associated with the electronics and communication engineering department

What are Procurement and Sourcing?

Procurement: The overarching process of acquiring goods and services that a company needs for its operations. It goes beyond simply buying things; procurement covers:

  • Identifying needs

  • Finding suppliers

  • Negotiating contracts

  • Ordering

  • Receiving goods/services

  • Payment processing

  • Managing supplier relationships


Sourcing:  A strategic part of procurement. It focuses on:

  • Researching the market to find potential suppliers

  • Evaluating suppliers based on cost, quality, reliability, sustainability, and risk factors

  • Selecting the best suppliers for the business's specific needs


Why is Learning Procurement and Sourcing Important for Companies and Managers?

  • Cost Savings: Effective procurement and sourcing finds the best value for money. This directly impacts the company's bottom line.

  • Efficiency: Streamlined processes in procurement avoid delays and bottlenecks in a company's operations.

  • Risk Mitigation: Thorough sourcing helps identify potential risks (like supply disruptions) and proactively manage them.

  • Competitive Advantage: Strong supplier relationships and access to quality materials or services can give companies an edge in the market.

  • Innovation: Sourcing can help uncover new technologies, materials, or processes that boost a company's offerings.


How Procurement and Sourcing Skills Build Global Careers

  • High Demand: Companies worldwide of all sizes need individuals who understand how to source and procure effectively.

  • Transferable Skills: The fundamentals of procurement and sourcing apply across industries and countries.

  • Cross-Functional Collaboration: Procurement interacts with many departments (finance, operations, legal), giving a broad view of how businesses function globally.

  • Growth Potential: As globalization increases, the need for professionals who understand the complexities of international procurement and supply chains will rise.

courseDetails.title: Fundamentals of Augmented Reality & Virtual Reality (101)
courseDetails.shortDescription: Augmented Reality, Virtual Reality, AR, VR, ARKit,ARCore, Unity3D, Unreal Engine, AR and VR applications
courseDetails.longDescription:
Fundamentals of Augmented Reality & Virtual Reality (101)

In today's rapidly evolving technological landscape, two terms have gained substantial prominence: Augmented Reality (AR) and Virtual Reality (VR). These immersive technologies have transformed the way we perceive and interact with the digital and physical worlds, offering experiences that were once thought to be confined to the realms of science fiction. This fundamental course will provide you with a comprehensive introduction to the fundamental concepts of Augmented Reality and Virtual Reality.

Understanding Augmented Reality (AR)

Augmented Reality is a technology that blends digital content with the real world, enhancing our perception of reality by overlaying computer-generated information onto our immediate surroundings. Unlike Virtual Reality, which creates an entirely simulated environment, AR integrates digital elements seamlessly into our existing physical environment. This integration is often experienced through devices such as smartphones, tablets, smart glasses, and heads-up displays.

Key Components of Augmented Reality:

  1. Real-World View: AR starts with the real-world view captured by the device's camera, serving as the canvas onto which digital content is overlaid.

  2. Computer Vision: This technology enables the AR system to understand and interpret the environment. It recognizes objects, surfaces, and their spatial relationships, allowing digital content to be placed accurately.

  3. Content Overlay: Digital content, such as 3D models, images, text, and videos, is superimposed onto the real-world view based on the device's understanding of the environment.

  4. User Interaction: AR applications often allow users to interact with the overlaid content. This interaction can include gestures, voice commands, and touch inputs.

Applications of Augmented Reality:

  1. Gaming: AR gaming apps like Pokémon Go have gained immense popularity by placing virtual characters and objects in the real world for players to interact with.

  2. Retail: AR can enhance the shopping experience by enabling customers to visualize products in their real environment before making a purchase.

  3. Education: AR is transforming education by bringing abstract concepts to life. It allows students to interact with 3D models, historical reconstructions, and more.

  4. Healthcare: Medical professionals use AR for tasks like surgical navigation, where relevant data is projected onto the surgeon's field of view.

Understanding Virtual Reality (VR)

Virtual Reality, on the other hand, transports users into entirely simulated environments, effectively replacing the physical world with a digital one. VR is typically experienced through specialized headsets that completely immerse users in a computer-generated reality, isolating them from their actual surroundings.

Key Components of Virtual Reality:

  1. Headset: VR headsets contain displays that cover the user's field of view and sensors that track head movements to adjust the displayed environment accordingly.

  2. Immersive Environment: VR environments are computer-generated and can simulate real-world settings or entirely fantastical worlds, limited only by the imagination of the creators.

  3. Motion Tracking: Sensors track not only head movements but also hand and body movements, allowing users to interact with the virtual world.

  4. Stereoscopic 3D: VR provides a sense of depth and scale by presenting slightly different images to each eye, mimicking how our eyes perceive the real world.

Applications of Virtual Reality:

  1. Gaming: VR gaming offers an unparalleled level of immersion, placing players directly within the game world.

  2. Training and Simulations: Industries such as aviation, military, and medicine use VR to create realistic training scenarios.

  3. Therapy and Rehabilitation: VR is employed as a therapeutic tool for phobias, PTSD treatment, and physical rehabilitation.

  4. Virtual Tourism: Users can virtually explore distant locations and historical periods, opening up new possibilities for travel and education.

The Blurring Line Between AR and VR:

As technology advances, the boundary between AR and VR is becoming increasingly blurred. Mixed Reality (MR) combines elements of both, seamlessly integrating digital content into the real world while allowing interactions. This technology holds the potential to revolutionize fields like design, collaboration, and entertainment.

In conclusion, Augmented Reality and Virtual Reality are two transformative technologies that offer unique ways to interact with digital information and immerse ourselves in new realities. Whether it's enhancing our surroundings with digital overlays or completely immersing ourselves in virtual worlds, AR and VR are shaping the future of human experience in countless domains. As these technologies continue to evolve, their impact on industries and society as a whole is only set to grow.

In this master course I would like to teach the 7 major topics:
1. Introduction to AR and VR

2. Core Technologies

3. AR & VR Development Platforms

4. User Interface and Interaction Design

5. Modeling and Content Creation

6. Integration of AI and machine learning in AR and VR

7. AR and VR (Augmented Reality and Virtual Reality) in Data Management

Enroll now and learn today !
